meta.name: SOLV 30/90 Challenge — Sales Call Playbook (Seed)

offer.oneLiner: Conversation-first French coaching with an autonomy-first system (DRY Method).

notes: This is a seed playbook. Edit language to match your voice.
Avoid guarantees. Keep claims realistic and individualized.

stages.name: Rapport & Frame
stages.goal: Set expectations, confirm purpose, get the lead talking.

stages.name: Diagnose (SPIN)
stages.goal: Understand situation, problems, implications, and desired outcome.

stages.name: Qualify (BANT-lite)
stages.goal: Confirm fit, time, authority, budget, and urgency.

stages.name: Present the Plan
stages.goal: Map their problems to your method and what happens next.

stages.name: Handle Objections
stages.goal: Diagnose, reframe, and resolve obstacles to decision.

stages.name: Close
stages.goal: Ask for the decision, choose payment option, complete checkout.

stages.name: Next Steps
stages.goal: If not closing today: schedule concrete follow-up or refer out.

checkpoints.label: Main problems in real conversations identified
Concrete next step (date/time or referral) set

questionBank.text: Quick plan: I'll ask a few questions about your French and your real-life situations, then I'll tell you honestly if this is a fit and what I'd recommend. If it is a fit, I'll show you how we'd get you to confident conversations. Sound good?
What would 'confident French conversations' look like for you in 90 days? Give me a real scene (who, where, what you want to say).
Where are you at today? (1) How often do you speak French now? (2) What situations do you avoid? (3) What level do you think you are?
Tell me about the last time you tried to speak French and it went badly. What happened, step by step?
If nothing changes, what does this cost you over the next 6–12 months?
questionBank.followUp: If you pick one, what's the most painful moment that keeps repeating?

questionBank.text: If we fast-forward 90 days and it worked — what are you doing differently in those conversations?
Realistically, how many hours per week can you commit to speaking-focused practice for the next 90 days?
If we decide it's a fit today, are you the one who can make the decision?
On a scale of 1–5, how comfortable are you investing 1497€ (or 3×499€) if it solves this speaking problem?
When do you want to start fixing this — now, or later?
Ok. Based on what you told me, here's what's actually blocking you — and how we'd fix it in a simple 90-day plan. I'll keep it concrete.
Before I map the plan: if you had to name ONE blocker that kills your conversations the most, what is it?
If the plan is speaking-first (not grammar-first) and we focus on real conversations from day 1, are you open to that approach?
Based on everything we discussed, I think this IS / ISN'T a fit. If it is a fit: do you want to enroll now and start this week?
Cool — what's the exact next step? (1) Book a follow-up time now, or (2) If it's not a fit, I'll point you to the best alternative path.

then.script: Based on your goal, this program is designed for speaking and real conversations. I don't want you paying for the wrong tool. If you want, tell me your exact goal and I'll recommend a better path.

then.reason: Time available is very low for meaningful speaking reps.
then.script: With less than ~3 hours/week, progress is usually slow because speaking needs reps. We can either (1) redesign your schedule to free time, or (2) pause until you can commit consistently.
Totally fine. To respect everyone's time, let's make the next step a short call with the decision maker present — and I'll keep it simple.

objectionLibrary.label: Too expensive
empathy: Totally fair — it's a meaningful investment.
diagnosticQuestions: Compared to what — what are you using as the reference point?
Is it that you can't afford it, or you're not sure it'll work for you?
reframes: What you're buying is speed + structure + feedback for speaking, not more content.
If we remove the biggest speaking blocker, that changes your daily life in the situations you described.
proofAngles: Use a specific story/testimonial placeholder: [INSERT: student who started speaking after years stuck].
Use a process proof: consistent speaking reps + feedback beats passive studying.
closeQuestions: If we can make the plan fit your budget (full vs 3×499€), are you ready to start?
What would need to be true for this to feel like a smart investment?

objectionLibrary.label: Need to think
diagnosticQuestions: What part do you need to think about — fit, timing, budget, or something else?
If you had to guess, what's the real hesitation?
reframes: Thinking is good — I just want to make sure it's not uncertainty we can resolve in 2 minutes.
If it's a fit, delaying usually keeps the same problem running.
proofAngles: Recap their stated consequences + urgency: [INSERT: their words].
closeQuestions: If we answer that one question right now, would you be comfortable deciding today?
If not today, when exactly will you decide?

objectionLibrary.label: Need to ask partner
empathy: Totally reasonable — it affects both of you.
diagnosticQuestions: What do you think your partner will care about most: money, time, or proof it works?
What's the decision process in your home — what do they need to hear?
reframes: Let's not leave it vague — we can set up a quick 10-minute call with both of you so I can answer questions directly.
If your partner's concern is risk, we can clarify expectations and whether you're a fit.
proofAngles: Use clarity: structure, time commitment, and realistic outcomes.
closeQuestions: Can we book a time with both of you now?
If your partner says yes, are you personally ready to start?

objectionLibrary.label: No time
empathy: Yeah — life is busy. I get it.
diagnosticQuestions: Is it truly no time, or no energy after work?
What's a realistic minimum you could commit to for 90 days?
reframes: Speaking improves with reps — we can design a plan around small daily reps rather than long sessions.
The goal is consistency, not perfection.
proofAngles: Use process proof: small consistent reps compound.
closeQuestions: If we design this around your schedule and keep it simple, are you in?
What would you need to change to free 3–5 hours/week?

objectionLibrary.label: Tried everything already
diagnosticQuestions: When you say everything, what did you actually do that involved speaking every week?
What part failed: consistency, feedback, confidence, or structure?
reframes: Most methods are content-heavy and conversation-light. Speaking needs targeted reps + feedback.
Your problem isn't effort — it's the strategy.
proofAngles: Use a story/testimonial placeholder: [INSERT: student stuck for years → started speaking].
closeQuestions: If the missing piece is structured speaking reps + feedback, would you try a 90-day plan?
What would make this attempt meaningfully different from the past?

objectionLibrary.label: I'm too old / bad at languages
empathy: I hear you — that belief is powerful.
diagnosticQuestions: What specifically happens when you try to speak — blank mind, anxiety, slow recall?
Have you ever improved a skill later in life with the right training?
reframes: Speaking confidence is trainable. The bottleneck is usually reps + feedback + fear, not age.
We focus on usable conversation patterns, not academic perfection.
proofAngles: Process proof: practice conditions + feedback loops.
closeQuestions: If we design the plan for your pace and confidence, are you willing to try 90 days?
What would 'progress' look like that would prove you wrong?

objectionLibrary.label: I'm not in France / no immersion
empathy: Yep — immersion helps, but it's not required.
diagnosticQuestions: How many real conversation opportunities do you have per week right now (even online)?
What situations do you want to handle — travel, work, friends?
reframes: We can create immersion-like reps through structured speaking sessions and real scenarios.
The key is consistent speaking under realistic constraints.
proofAngles: Explain how structured reps simulate real conversations.
closeQuestions: If we can create those reps without living in France, are you in?
Do you want to solve this now or keep waiting for the 'perfect' environment?

objectionLibrary.label: I want grammar first
diagnosticQuestions: When you studied grammar in the past, did it translate into speaking confidence?
What's the real fear — making mistakes out loud?
reframes: We don't ignore grammar — we use it as-needed, in context, so it supports speaking.
Speaking-first builds speed and confidence; then grammar locks in accuracy.
closeQuestions: If we do grammar only when it helps your speaking, would you try that approach?
If you keep doing grammar-first, what do you expect will change?

objectionLibrary.label: I can just use an app / tutor
diagnosticQuestions: What's missing with apps/tutors you tried: structure, accountability, feedback, or real speaking reps?
Do you want random lessons, or a plan designed around your exact conversation goals?
reframes: Apps are great for input. Speaking confidence needs guided practice + feedback loops.
A tutor can be hit-or-miss; we're building a consistent system around your goal.
proofAngles: Use process proof: system + reps + feedback.
closeQuestions: If you had a clear 90-day speaking plan with accountability, would you prefer that over random lessons?
What would make you choose this instead of experimenting again?

positioning.oneSentence: This is for adults who want confident French conversations — we focus on speaking first, with an autonomy-first system that creates consistent reps and feedback.
whatWeDontDo: We don't optimize for exams unless speaking is the goal.
We don't promise magic results — we build a repeatable speaking process.

presentPlanTemplate: Here's what I heard: [RESTATE their goal in their words].
So the plan is: (1) speaking reps built around your real scenes, (2) feedback + correction in context, (3) a simple autonomy system so you don't depend on motivation.
If you do the reps consistently, you should notice: more speed, fewer freezes, more confidence in the exact situations you described.

closeNow.ask: Do you want to enroll now and start this week?
closeNow.paymentOptionPrompt: Do you prefer 1497€ pay-in-full, or the 3×499€ plan?
closeNow.checkoutInstruction: Awesome — I'll send you the checkout link now. When you've completed it, tell me and we'll confirm the next steps.

disqualify.kindNo: I don't think this is the best fit for what you want. I'd rather be honest than sell you something misaligned.
disqualify.redirectQuestion: What is the real outcome you want (speaking, exam, writing, travel), and by when?
disqualify.referOutGeneric: Based on that, I'd recommend [INSERT: alternative path]. If you want, I can share a simple plan you can follow on your own.

followUpIfNotToday.clarify: What exactly needs to happen before you can decide?
followUpIfNotToday.setDeadline: When will you decide — and can we book a time now?
followUpIfNotToday.emailSummaryTemplate: Recap: goal, blockers, plan, next step date/time.

processProof: Speaking confidence requires reps under realistic constraints.
Feedback in context beats studying rules in isolation.

then.reason: Time constraint can block results; redesign schedule or disqualify.
Align on speaking-first approach before closing.
